snippet: A federal judge asks why no one has been prosecuted when there is a widespread conclusion that fraud at every level permeated the bubble in mortgage-backed securities.
abstract: Teresa Tritch Editorial Observer column examines Federal Judge Jed Rakoff's analysis to determine why no prominent banker has been prosecuted for fraud in the wake of the financial crisis; notes Rakoff suggests that a shift from focusing on corporations rather than individuals explains the lack of prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge asks why no one has been prosecuted when there is a widespread conclusion that fraud at every level permeated the bubble in mortgage-backed securities.

headline.print_headline: Why Bankers Have Gotten a Pass
headline.main: Why Bankers Have Gotten a Pass
